deck: Vandenreich is an army of Quincies that aim to destroy Soul Society. They are lead by their Emperor, Yhwach.
description:
The Vandenreich are a group of exceptionally powerful Quincy who somehow survived the genocide that Soul Society committed against them centuries prior the beginning of BLEACH. Their name in Japanese (見えざる帝国 (ヴァンデンライヒ), Vandenraihi) means "Invisible Empire". Under the orders of Emperor Yhwach, they conquered Hueco Mundo, imprisoning the new ruler Tia Harribel and using the remaining Arrancars living in Las Noches as cannon fodder for their war.

Members

Stern Ritter

The Vandenreich’s strongest warriors go to form the ranks of the Stern Ritter elite, and each of them is identified by a letter and a battle name bestowed by the Emperor himself. Known Stern Ritters are:

  • A: Yhwach (Emperor) and Uryu Ishida
  • B: Jugram Haschwalth, Grand Master of the Stern Ritters.
  • D: Askin Nakk Le Vaar
  • E: Bambietta Basterbine
  • F: Äs Nödt The Fear
  • G: Liltotto Lamperd
  • H: Bazz-B The Heat
  • I: Cang Du The Iron
  • J: Quilge Opie The Jail
  • K: BG9
  • L: Pepe Waccabrada The Love
  • O: Driscoll Berci The Overkill
  • P: Meninas McAllon
  • Q: Berenice Gabrielli The Question
  • R: Jerome Guizbatt The Roar
  • S: Mask De Masculine The Superstar
  • T: Candice Catnipp
  • U: NaNaNa Najahkoop
  • Y: Loyd Lloyd & Royd Lloyd The Yourself
  • Z: Giselle Gewelle
  • ?: Shaz Domino

Jagdarmee

The Jagdarmee (狩猟部隊 (ヤークトアルメー), Yākutoarumē) is the Hunting Squad of Hueco Mundo. Their mission is to capture Arrancars, find the strongest and most skilled ones and forcibly enroll them into their army to fight their war. Their leader, the First Jagdarmee Quilge Opie, is a strong enough warrior that the Emperor granted him a letter and a battle name like the Stern Ritter.

Soldat

The Soldat (聖兵 (ゾルダート), Zorudāto)

Arrancar

The Vandenreich has subjugated several strong Arrancar from Hueco Mundo. They were drafted into the army of the Vandenreich and used as expendable fodder.

  • Asguiaro Ebern
  • Luders Friegen
name: Vandenreich

deck: Team Takashi are a group of students from Fujimi High School who survived the outbreak to search for their families.
description:
Team Takashi is the protagonist group from the Highschool of the Dead that was written by Daisuke Sato and illustrated by Shouji Sato. The series first began serialization in Fujimi Shobo's Monthly Dragon Age magazine in July 2006. After several of their trials, Takashi was officially asked by the members to be their leader. They are primarily made up of students and a teacher from Fujimi High School that escaped the outbreak of Them (the title given to the zombies) together.

The team first came together in Hightschool of the Dead Volume 1 CH. 2 "Escape from the Dead", and

Members

Major Story Arcs

Other Media

Anime

Highschool of the Dead

Team Takashi made it's first anime appearance was in Highschool of the Dead - Episode 2 "Escape from the Dead".
name: Team Takashi

deck: A group of warriors, active in the year 2050. Both enemies and friends to a time-displaced Jonah Hex.
name: Dogs of War

deck: A race of extra-dimensional, carnivorous insects
description:
Origin

The Scatter's origin is uncertain. They originated in an extra-dimensional area, and eventually developed the capability to move from world to world, destroying every planet they came across. At some point they attached themselves to the villain Lore, and, guided by Century, followed in her destructive wake, consuming the remainders of planets she left behind.

Creation

The Scatter were created by Dan Abnett, Andy Lanning, and Tom Tenney.

Team Evolution

The Scatter is composed of vast swarms of insects that are essentially identical and interchangeable.

Major Story Arcs

Force Works

Century is accidentally summoned to Earth by the Scarlet Witch, and the Scatter follow after him, capturing the Scarlet Witch, Spider-Woman and USAgent, and apparently killing Wonder Man. They are eventually defeated by Century, Iron Man, and other members of Force Works.

Powers and Abilities

The Scatter is an incredibly intelligent race, having developed and mastered advanced wormhole technology that can be used to travel through space. They tend to appear in massive bodies which are actually hives containing thousands of the insectoid Scatter. These bodies are superhumanly strong and durable, and possess very sharp claws. A carnivorous race, members of the Scatter are able to enter a victim by travelling under their skin, and consume them from the inside out

issue_credits.name: Wolverine: The Best There Is: Broken Quarantine
Southern Showdown as FW Delivers Deathblow to the Alien Scatter!
Wolverine der Best von Allen: Schluss mit Lustig

name: The Scatter

volume_credits.name: Wolverine: The Best There Is: Broken Quarantine
Iron Man/War Machine: Hands of the Mandarin
Wolverine: The Best There Is - The Complete Series

deck:
Originally from the Banari homeworld, the Haab are a water-breathing race created by the Banari to serve them. They possess superhuman strength, have sharp teeth, and have simple minds. 
Without proper guidance from their masters, they will only seek out food.

issue_credits.name: Hands Across the Water, Hands Across the Skies ...

name: Haab

deck: Teenage superhero team.
description:
Origin

One of the two main teenage superhero teams the Young Americans exemplify chaste, clean, conservative Christian living as opposed to the Teenage Kix who practice a more edgy and wild team attitude and persona. Lead by Drummer Boy, the Young Americans is made up of Starlight, Holy Mary, General Issue and The Standard. The Young Americans are an updated revamp of a World War 2 era superhero team also known as the Young Americans. The Young Americans are Vought-American sponsored but also are associated with various Christian youth groups as well with the Young Republicans.

Creation

The Young Americans are a Dynamite Entertainment comic book team, created by Garth Ennis and Darick Robertson. They appear in The Boys series and are first depicted in The Boys #20. One of their members Starlight is a main character of the series and references her old team occasionally.

issue_credits.name: I Tell You No Lie, G.I., Part Two

name: Young Americans

deck: An alien race that needs to sacrifice other races in order to perpetuate their own.
description:
Major Story Arcs

Legion of the Damned

Initially introduced in the Legion of Super-Heroes by the forerunner Atrophos, the Blight are an alien race that requires the life energies of other species in order to perpetuate itself. They are an unstoppable engine of domination, constantly able to generate new members of their species through a form of mind control. The Blight nearly conquered and laid waste to the entire Earth and several surrounding planets as well, if not for the unrelenting resistance of the Legion.

Red Hood and the Outlaws

The Blight are reintroduced in the New 52 attacking the planet Tamaran. Some of their conversation suggests that they show the royalty of planets they conquer some respect, though this does not extend beyond simple pleasantries as they simply see them as a means to prolong their survival. They use the warm bodies of planets that they take over as incubators for their unborn.

issue_credits.name: The Moon's Up, and the Sun's Down -- and a Thousand Starry Eyes Have Caught Me Dying!
We Are Family--Come On Everybody and Die!
Star's Fading, But I Linger on, Dear--Still Craving Your Death!; Still Raging--After ALl These Years!
Legion of the Damned, Part Four: Damned For All Eternity!
Legion of the Damned, Part Two: Damned If We Do!
Legion of the Damned, Part Three: Damned If We Don't!
Legion Of The Damned, Part One

name: Blight

volume_credits.name: Legion of Super-Heroes Secret Files And Origins
DC Comics Presents: Legion of Super-Heroes
Red Hood and the Outlaws: The Starfire

deck: A team of brothers who compete in the Tournament of the Titans.
description:
Origin

When Odin decides to hold the Tournament of Titans, it requires mighty warriors to participate in the event. A team of brothers, the Warriors of the Thousand Galaxies join the tournament to test themselves. Consisting of the strong and large Brok the Crusher, the small but powerful Drom the Spirit Weaver, the swordsman Tyr of the Blinding Blade, and the mace fighter Galp of the Steel Arm. The brothers start a brawl in an Asgardian tavern and proceed to mock the Asgardians, however they would find themselves face to face with the Warriors Three and Thor after that incident, their official opponents at the Tournament of the Titans. After a small scuffle they decide to wait until the tournament to settle things, however on the day of the Tournament the devastating Destroyer armor attacks all the combatants, the two teams of warriors joining forces with Odin to bring the living armor down. During the tournament, Brok challenged Thor as he was the strongest, Tyr dueled with Fandral, as both were sword masters. Galp challenged Hogun, as both bore lethal mace clubs. Which left Drom and Volstagg to do battle.    

Creation

The Warriors of the Thousand Galaxies are a Marvel comic book team created by Stan Lee, Jack Kirby and Vince Colletta. The team first appear in Thor Annual #2 released in 1966. The team possess parallel similarities with the Warriors Three, naturally given they were essentially created to act as a foe for each character, specifically Galp for Hogun, Tyr for Fandral and Drom for Volstagg. It should be noted that the Tyr here is not in anyway associated with the Asgardian war god Tyr.
name: The Warriors of the Thousand Galaxies

deck: A trio of Dr. Eggman's Metal Series robots sent to attack New Mobotropolis.
name: Team Metal

deck: Dr. Eggman's latest series of badniks.
name: Metal Series

volume_credits.name: Sonic the Hedgehog Complete Comic Encyclopedia

name: Old Ones

Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Nine: Welcome to the Team
Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Nine: The Core

deck: Two genetically altered boars created by Bruce Banner in an effort to recreate the Hulk
description:
Origin

Separated from the Hulk, Bruce Banner began attempting to recreate the accident that had created the Hulk. To this end, he began irradiating animals with gamma radiation. His 26th and 27th experiments were a pair of boars who gained limited intelligence, super strength, and a fanatical devotion to Banner from their exposure to the radiation. 

Creation

The Boar Brothers were created by Jason Aaron and Marc Silvestri. 

Team Evolution

The Boar Brothers is composed of 26 and 27. They are loyal to Bruce Banner, who directs and controls them. 

Major Story Arcs

Hulk Asunder 

The Brothers are sent by their "father" to hunt down the Hulk, who has sequestered himself in the Moloid caves. They kidnap the children of the Moloid tribe to draw him out, and engage in a fierce battle with the Hulk that literally shakes the Earth. They are defeated after a brutal battle when one brother plunges through a hole in the Earth's crust, and the other brother chooses to follow after him rather than fight on alone.
name: Boar Brothers

volume_credits.name: The Incredible Hulk By Jason Aaron

deck: Federal Advisory Committee to Thunderbolts
description: F.A.C.T. are responsible for assembling a new Thunderbolts team composed of some of Norman Osborn's incarcerated allies.

issue_credits.name: The Word at the Jilted Cage...

name: F.A.C.T.

volume_credits.name: Dark Avengers: The End Is The Beginning

deck: In a future after the Rigellian Cataclysm, Boss Enforcement Council are a futuristic group of police enforcers that have total authority over criminal handling.
description:
Origin

Shortly after the Cataclysm, martial law was declared all over the globe and the mutation rate skyrocketed, with many traits of existing mutants and paranormals being transferred and multiplied. In time only mutants could reproduce and everyone else had to be cloned. Captain America recruited as many super beings as he could to create an entire army of Avengers. In time they passed on their technologies and donated genetic material which led to the Boss Enforcement Council.

Creation

The Boss Enforcement Council were created by Jeff Parker although blatantly and admittedly is inspired by Judge Dredd.

Team Evolution

Captain America, Punisher, Venom, Wolverine, Luke Cage, Ms. Marvel, Iron Man, Nova and Cyclops are all seen as part of Captain America's Avengers Army - whether they were actual members of the "Avengers" or the Boss Enforcement Council is not shown.

Major Story Arcs

Cataclysm

The Thunderbolts are sent forward into the future where they encounter Boss Cage, a member of the Boss Enforcement Council, who targets them as being curfew-breaking mutants. After a battle with the team in which Boss Cage is defeated, he turns to a last resort and nukes the entire area. Boss Cage is later decommissioned by the Boss Enforcement Council and vengefully seeks to get even with the Thunderbolts who cost him his job and only passion in life.

issue_credits.name: Theirs is a Land With a Wall Around It...

name: Boss Enforcement Council

volume_credits.name: Dark Avengers: The End Is The Beginning
Captain Britain and the Mighty Defenders

deck: The mutants of a dystopian future, scorned by the humans, became Outlanders hunted and persecuted simply for existing.
description:
Origin

After the Rigellian Cataclysm, the mutation rate skyrocketed, with many traits of existing mutants and paranormals being transferred and multiplied. In time only mutants could reproduce and everyone else had to be cloned. In a mirror to the pre-Cataclysm state, again the mutants were hated by the "humans" and driven to the outskirts of society.

Creation

The Outlanders were created by Jeff Parker and Kev Walker and first appeared in Dark Avengers #178.

Team Evolution

Not much is known about the Outlanders, except they are constantly hounded and targeted by the Boss Enforcement Council and in particular Boss Cage. Members of the Outlanders display genetic similarities and mutations to several classic mutants and superhumans such as Nightcrawler and Doctor Octopus.
name: Outlanders

volume_credits.name: Dark Avengers: The End Is The Beginning

deck: Puppet stars of BBC's Watch With Mother, who went on to star in their own comic strips.
description:
Origin

Bill and Ben live inside two flowerpots next to the garden's potting shed, emerging whenever the gardener is away. Their friend is Little Weed, a flower growing between their pots.

Creation

Bill and Ben first appeared in Flower Pot Men, a segment of the BBC's Watch With Mother, a show aimed at very young children. The two puppets were voiced by Peter Hawkins, later to voice the Daleks, Captain Pugwash and Rainbow's Zippy, amongst many others. The characters swiftly transited to comic strips too, appearing in Hulton Press' Robin.

issue_credits.name: Strange Doors That We Never Closed Again

name: Bill and Ben, the Flowerpot Men

deck: Warlike alien race that take payment in meat. Have a habit of eating their fallen foes.
description:
Origin

Kleggs are crocodilian alien species who take mercenary work in return for fresh meat as payment - usually this is in the form of their opponents, but tyrants sometimes use their unfortunate subjects as currency to procure the Kleggs.

Creation

Kleggs first appeared in 2000 AD Prog 94 in the Judge Dredd strip, created by John Wagner, Alan Grant and Brian Bolland.

issue_credits.name: The Day the Law Died TPB

name: Kleggs

volume_credits.name: Judge Dredd: The Judge Child Quest
Judge Dredd: The Day the Law Died

deck: Killer plants created by John Wyndham.
description:
Origin

Triffids are mobile carnivorous plants, able to blind and kill prey with a deadly stinger.

Creation

The Triffids were created by British author John Wyndham for his 1951 novel Day of the Triffids, which was subsequently adapted into comic strip form by Gerry Conway, Ross Andru, Ernie Chan and Rico Rival for Unknown Worlds of Science Fiction #1.
name: Triffids

deck: A diving team that fight the Sea Devils.
name: Black Mantas

deck: Secret organisation who use their Thunderbird vehicles to protect the world from disasters, both man-made and natural.
description:
Origin

Founded in the 2060s by ex-astronaut Jeff Tracy, International Rescue is dedicated to protecting people around the world when disaster strikes, using their advanced Thunderbird vehicles and operating out of the remote Tracy Island.

Creation

Made after Stingray and prior to Captain Scarlet, Thunderbirds was the creation of puppet-show maestro Gerry Anderson, and is arguably his best known series. Characters and concepts from the show, most notably Lady Penelope, debuted in comic form in TV Century 21 #1 the week of 23rd January 1965, while the series was still being produced; the show itself began airing on television on 30th September 1965. It lasted two seasons, with the final episode first airing on Christmas Day 1966.
name: International Rescue

deck: Team Of Bounty Hunter consist Of Ian Glover, father Jon Glover and Aqira.
name: Nighthunter

deck: A group of radically-minded bowlers bent on destruction.
name: League of Nazi Bowlers

deck: Bloodthirsty robot savages who planned to use Jean Grey School for Higher Learning to power their invasion of Earth.
name: Robo-Barbarians

deck: Spooks for hire.
description:
Origin

Run by a headless ghost, Rent-a-Ghost Ltd. provides a wide variety of spooks for hire, usually by clients who want someone scared. However, their services frequently backfire on those who hire them.

Creation

Rent-a-Ghost Ltd. was created by Reg Parlett and first appeared in Buster's 4th January 1969 issue. They enjoyed a decade long run there, before shuffling back off this mortal coil with their final installment on 16th June 1979.

Notes

Rent-a-Ghost Ltd's success prompted other comics to produce similarly themed strips, such as Cor!!'s Hire a Horror (also drawn by Reg Parlett). However, despite the virtually identical names, there is no confirmed connection between Rent-a-Ghost Ltd. and the BBC's television series Rentaghost, which debuted during the latter part of the Buster strip's run.
name: Rent-a-Ghost Ltd.

deck: Ninja sect that targeted Elektra, but were defeated. Later assasinated by the Black Swan, although the credit went to Deadpool.
description:
Ninja order based in the region of Ningxia Hui, China, it was formed in the 11th century under the lead of the ereditary Master of the Four winds.

His warriors can be summoned by the master's will, and once one of them dies or is killed, a new replacement takes it role.
name: Four Winds

deck: A group with plans to overthrow the crown who fought the Avengers (Steed and Mrs. Peel) numerous times
description:
Origin

The club, lead by John Cleverly Cartney, wanted to overthrow the crown. However, The Avengers, John Steed and Emma Peel defeated them and Cartney apparently fell to his death.

Creation

The Hellfire Club was created for the '60s British TV series The Avengers episode titled "A Touch of Brimstone". The writers of the show were inspired by the actual Hellfire Club of 18th century Ireland.

This Hellfire Club, in turn, would inspire the Marvel's Hellfire Club. Emma Peel's costume as the "Queen of Sin" would inspire X-men character Emma Frost.

In 2012, Mark Waid , a former X-men writer, revamped the group for Steed and Mrs. Peel's new ongoing series.

Major Arcs

Dead Future

After a number of spy's deaths, Steed and Emma go to investigate the Hellfire Club. They meet Ian Landowne Dunderdale Cartney, astro secretary of the new Hellfire Club. However, they soon learn nothing is what it seems and the club is back it's old tricks.
name: The Hellfire Club

volume_credits.name: Steed and Mrs. Peel: A Very Civil Armageddon

deck: Company renting out the services of monsters in Cor!!
description:
Origin

Fronted out of an innocent looking office run by a pretty young woman, Hire a Horror provides the unusual service of renting out various monsters, ranging from vampires, witches and Frankenstein Monsters to more unique creatures. However, it is fairly common for the clients to find that hiring monsters backfires on them.

Creation

Hire a Horror first appeared in Cor!! #1, and was drawn by Reg Parlett. The popular strip lasted for the entire duration of the comic's run, but when Cor!! was merged into Buster, it proved too similar to that title's existing series Rent-a-Ghost, and so Hire a Horror shut up shop.
name: Hire a Horror

name: Organizzazione

deck: Tiny clones of Scrapper (from the Newsboy legion).
description:
Origin

Scrapper troopers were cloned from the DNA of Scrapper, by the DNA-project. They were (probably) created to be a miniature combat-team, that can do what a "normal" sized soldier can do, but obviously, in a more smaller way.

Creation

Scrapper troopers were created by Jack Kirby.

Current Events

Presumably, the troopers haven`t appeared Post-Crisis. And neither in the New 52.

Powers & Abilities

Scrapper Troopers were ordinary, peak human/trained soldiers, but with DNA enhancements to shrink down to unfathomable sizes to operate in special missions.
name: Scrapper Troopers

deck: Miniature green plastic soldiers who belong to Andy Davis. They are often called upon by Woody to go on reconnaissance missions due to their professional nature, exceptional teamwork and discipline.
description:
Origin

It is unknown exactly when the Bucket O' Soldier's were produced and marketed or when Andy Davis acquired them.

Creation

The Bucket O' Soldier's were created by Pixar for the movie Toy Story.

Team Evolution

Originally there were an upwards of 200 Toy Soldiers in the bucket; however, by the time the events of Toy Story 3 only 3 soldiers were left. While many of the soldiers were thrown away over a course of many years, there is a case of one soldier by the name of Corporal Thomas who was "lost" during an event known only as the Lawnmower Incident.

While not all of the soldiers are named, a select few have been given titles:

  • Sarge
  • Private Benjamin
  • Captain Shields
  • Mr. Plastic Explosives
  • Private F.C. Mojo
  • Corporal Thomas (Lost/Destroyed)
  • Thorpe
  • Gordon the Paratrooper
  • Private Jensen

Major Story Arcs

Toy Story

Sarge and his Bucket O' Soldiers are called upon by Woody during Andy's birthday party; their main job being to perform reconnaissance & report to the other toys what presents Andy received. During this mission one of the soldiers was stepped on by Mrs. Davis, nearly crushing him. Despite the soldier's pleas to move on without him, Sarge lifted the soldier and helped him into a nearby potted plant as one of their main rules is that no man is ever left behind.

The Bucket O' Soldiers also attack Woody after he pushes Buzz Lightyear out of Andy's bedroom window; however, their attack fails as Andy begins entering the room forcing all the toys to go limp.

Toy Story 2

The Bucket O' Soldiers are seen trying to hold a door shut along with Rocky Gibraltar; however, they aren't strong enough & Andy's dog, Buster, barges in.

Toy Story 3

After a failed attempt to get Andy to play with his toys again, dubbed Operation Playtime, the remaining Bucket O' Soldiers realize that Andy is too grown up and it's time for them to move onto new things. By the end of the film they wind up at Sunnyside Daycare and are taken in by Barbie & Ken.
name: Bucket O' Soldiers

deck: Cold-blooded reptialian Martians, often foes and occasional allies of the Doctor.

issue_credits.name: The Missing Episodes: The Second Doctor: Volume Two

name: Ice Warriors

volume_credits.name: It's Even Bigger on the Inside

deck: The Yeti are ape-like creatures from Nepalese and Tibetan folklore.
description:
In Doctor Who:

The Yeti first appeared in the Doctor Who story The Abominable Snowmen, and returned in The Web of Fear, both times opposing the second Doctor (played by Patrick Troughton), and for a brief cameo in The Five Doctors. The appeared in the comics for the first time in Yonder...The Yeti, a back-up story in Doctor Who Monthly.

The Yeti are robots constructed by individuals who have been taken over by the bodiless intellect of the Great Intelligence. Initially utilised in Tibet, the Intelligence later set up base in London using one of the Yeti robots that had been transported there, and, after replicating additional Yeti robots, it attacked the city, using the London Underground as its base.

deck: Before superheroes, there were Masks! Masks is a group of vigilantes united together against a newly formed fascist police force that has taken over New York. When the law is unjust, justice must be an outlaw!
description:
Creation

All the members of Masks are previously existing character and no new characters were created for the group. The team Masks was created by writer Chris Roberson and artist Alex Ross.
name: Masks

deck: A group of Red Skull's followers bent on the destruction of mutantkind.
description:
Origin

The S-Men is made up of people who have all suffered atrocities at the hands of mutants during their life, including those who have seen their families slaughtered by evil mutants. With the help of the Red Skull and Arnim Zola, these people have gone through lengthy and painful genetic alterations in order to gain the powers they now possess. Their goal is to get rid of all mutants.

Creation

The S-Men were created by writer Rick Remender and artist John Cassaday. The team first appeared in Uncanny Avengers #1.

Major Story Arcs

Uncanny Avengers

The S-Men arrived at Charles Xavier's grave and kidnapped the mourning Rogue and Scarlet Witch. They also took with them the deceased body of Professor X. Upon receiving the body, The Red Skull removed a part of Xavier's brain and managed to merge it with his own thus gaining Xavier's powers. Red Skull and the S-Men then launched an attack on Manhattan where Red Skull used his mind control powers to force all humans to start killing mutants. A bloody massacre followed but the S-Men were eventually stopped by the Uncanny Avengers.

issue_credits.name: .NOW The Iron Nail, Prologue: A Decision

name: S-Men

deck: A murderous sect of tiny people who live in the Microverse. Trapped outside their dimension, The Microns allied with Carnage to find a way back to the Microverse.

issue_credits.name: Minimum Carnage; Part 3; The Madman & the Microverse

name: Microns

deck: A group existing in various forms over the years whose members set aside their differences to try and prevent what they deem as extensive threats to the Earth and its people.
description: Known to have existed before the Second World War with a number of different members, in 1935, the group now consisting of Vanessa Baker, Murderous Lion, Jefferson Chambers, The Menace, Wyatt Crowley, and Ulysses Bloodstone hired Wolverine to kill the Dreaming Maiden, a being who was a beacon to a "celestial" evil that threatened mankind. Then in 1942, the group tried during World War II to offer a seat to Namor, The Sub-Mariner, but he refused. Sometime afterward they disbanded due to differing outlooks on how to avoid destruction. All members would continue to live on with their own lives (though Bloodstone would die years later). When the Dreaming Maiden started dreaming again, she promised each member "that which they desired" which turned them against one another in searching for her. This again brought Wolverine into the mix along with the daughter of Covenant member Ulysses Bloodstone, Elsa Bloodstone. After the Maiden was killed, old members Vanessa Baker, Murderous Lion, Jefferson Chambers, and Wyatt Crowley met together with Elsa Bloodstone and a female version of The Menace to "get back down to business."
name: The Covenant

deck: Previous group of students sent to Morning Glory Academy by Abraham

deck: Sentient weapons developed by The Reach, they bond with a host and force the will of The Reach upon them.
description: Originally an insectoid race found on one of the planets conquered by the Reach, the species would dig into the bodies of larger organisms and then assume control of their nervous system. The Reach developed this into a bioweapon. With their alterations, they affix themselves to a planet's dominant lifeforms, taking over and using the knowledge it gains from its host to destroy their defenses.

deck: Interstellar freebooters who crew the starship Osprey.
description:
Origin

The Travellers are are freebooters and mercenaries who seek profit across space in their spaceship the Osprey. The group includes the Osprey's owner Captain Horatio Flinn, the kill-krazy marine James "Mad Gav" Gavin, fixer and space pervert Jason DiNalt, the clumsy scout Hannibal Jeremiah Hayes, and sensual medic Syrena Medussa, as well as their pet / mascot Felix, a Dawlri from the planet Palitoy.

Creation

The Travellers were created by Mark Harrison as a humorous take on the Science-Fiction space opera role-playing game Traveller and the characters people tended to play in the game. They first appeared in Games Workshop's RPG magazine White Dwarf #45 in 1983, and their strip continued there until 1986.
name: Travellers

deck: The mercenary group Chainsaw are Project Rising Spirit's earlier attempt at making human/technology hybrids.
description:
Creation

Chainsaw were created by writer Duane Swierczynski and artists Arturo Lozzi and Manuel Garcia. They first appeared in the story "The Rise and Fall, Part 1" in Bloodshot #5 (Nov. 2012).
name: Chainsaw

deck: One of the many noble houses of Gemworld.
description:
Opportunists in the struggles in Gemworld.

New 52

In the New 52 reboot, Lord Reishan is the leader of House Diamond. His sons, in order of birth, are Zushan, Hadran, and Talzanar. With Lord Reishan, and later Eclipso, as leader, they stand in stark comparison with House Amethyst-- the evil contrasting with the good. While Lord Reishan, Zushan, and Eclipso are forces of evil, Hadran and his younger brother Talzanar seem to favor a different, more well-natured path. Hadran even assists Amethyst, one of House Diamond's most hated figureheads.

The Blood of Amethyst; Chapter Two: Iron Trolls

deck: Servants of Sauron in his quest for the One Ring
description:
History

Also known as the Ring Wraiths, the Nazgûl were once kings of men before being fooled by Sauron. They took the nine Rings of Power he offered them and slowly bent to his evil will. The Nazgûl are neither living nor dead and tirelessly search for the One Ring - Sauron's master ring that will ensure his dominion over all life on Middle Earth.

movies.name: The Hobbit: Battle of the Five Armies
The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring

name: Nazgûl

deck: A Firestorm is a person who can use the Firestorm Protocol to gain the powers of matter & energy transmutation/manipulation, force blasts, flight, physical enhancement and other abilities depending on the skill of the user. In the New 52 there are many who are working together against a common enemy.
description:
Overview

Firestorms became weapons after Zithertech was able to manufacture them and sell them to countries, effectively becoming the next stage in weapons-of –mass-destruction because they were walking nuclear reactors. Firestorms also became black market goods, some having fallen into the hands of weapons dealers and worth a billion dollars apiece. All Firestorms have similar powers; the main limit is the skill and proficiency of the user and the stability of the Firestorm Matrix itself. Jason Rusch and Ronnie Raymond also possessed the power to combine with other Firestorms to create larger and more powerful yet harder to control beings.

During the battle in Pakistan against the Rogue Firestorms and Pozhar it was revealed that only Jason, Ronnie, and Pozhar had untainted Firestorm Protocols as the ones manufactured by Zithertech had fail-safes that allowed them to be shut remotely.

Members

Individuals

Jason Rusch

Jason is one of the original Firestorms. He was given the ability directly from Doctor Martin Stein, the inventor of the Firestorm Protocols. He goes to school with Ronnie Raymond and is adept at matter transmutation, having a think first, act second mentality.

Status: Alive

Ronnie Raymond

Ronnie gained the power when Jason became Firestorm in school and gained the ability as well. He was very physical with his abilities and did not appreciate them as much. He was trained somewhat by Pozhar to control his abilities and became stronger. He has an act first, think second mentality that often puts him at odds with Jason.

Status: Alive

Pozhar

Pozhar, real name unknown, is a very powerful Russian Firestorm who helped Martin Stein work on the original Protocols and as such, has a much deeper understanding of them than everyone else. He made it his mission to eventually kill all other Firestorms as he saw them as thieves who stole his work. He spent some time training Ronnie Raymond to become more adept with his powers and become a soldier in his war. He was killed when he was forcibly separated from Scorn.

Status: Deceased

Firehawk

Firehawk, first name Therese, last name unknown, is the French Firestorm and presumably was once a soldier. She met Jason in France while he was pursuing a Rogue Firestorm trying to blow up the Eiffel Tower and she also met the Justice League International as well. She accompanied Jason to Russia to help find answers about Stein before leaving. They met again in the Battle of Pakistan where she nearly died at the hands of Scorn. She survived and killed Director Zither at the Zithertech compound. Her ultimate fate is unknown.

Status: Unknown

Hurricane

Hurricane, real name unknown, is an English Firestorm and was once a soldier. He met Jason in France while he was pursuing a Rogue Firestorm trying to blow up the Eiffel Tower and he also met the Justice League International as well. They met again in the Battle of Pakistan where he died at the hands of Scorn.

Status: Deceased

Raksashi

Raksashi is a female Indian Firestorm whose protocol was bought from Zithertech. She knew Pozhar from before the series started and didn’t trust him. She was friendly, if not stern to Ronnie and Jason. She died in the Battle of Pakistan when Director Zither activated the fail-safe in her protocol, killing her after she was beaten in a fight with Scorn.

Status: Deceased

Al-Faristaa

Al-Faristaa was a Quraci black market arms dealer who sold Firestorm Protocols and used one on himself. He sold one for a billion dollars to loyalist members in a civil war before being confronted by Pozhar who told him that he was using flawed protocols. He was killed by Pozhar after losing a fight above the Red Sea shortly thereafter.

Status: Deceased

Qurac Terrorist

The Qurac Terrorist was a man who stormed a concert with several other men much to the confusion of the crowd. He was confronted by Jason and Ronnie but was able to get away just long enough to detonate himself and kill all of the concert-goers. Jason and Ronnie survived.

Status: Deceased

Helix

A former soldier and husband to Director of Zithertech, Candace Zither, Helix was unique because he is as big as a combined Firestorm and was more powerful than a regular one. It took the might of Fury to stop him by decapitating him. He eventually returns and crashes a football game before the combined Firestorm of Ronnie and Jason bring him to the upper atmosphere and detonate him, finally killing him.

Status: Deceased

Rogue Firestorms

Rouge Firestorms are dangerous knockoffs of regular Firestorms that are easy to make at the cost of stability because their protocol is made using shortcuts but they are easy to mass produce. It was suspected but never confirmed that they were targeting Zithertech and countries using their Firestorms but they also were after Pozhar for reasons unknown. Raksashi called them Ashra Khan. There were hundreds of them before they were wiped out in the Battle of Pakistan.

Status: Deceased

Combined Firestorms

Combined Firestorms occur when two Firestorms combine their powers into one, larger and more powerful, yet more difficult to control being. This appeared to be a special ability of Jason Rusch and Ronnie Raymond seeing as all combinations involved one of them and Firehawk was very surprised that it happened. She theorized that it was because he and Jason were only half of the Firestorm Protocol that allowed them to do this but Jason wasn’t sure. It seems to take severe emotional shock to trigger the reaction, primarily anger.

The two creators exist inside of the quantum field and can fully interact with each other and either one or both can control the body or have the separate entity of the combined form take over. Therefore it is difficult to say whether the combined Firestorm is a combination of the two people or a new separate entity. Being in the quantum field hurt Firehawk but seemed to have no effect on Ronnie, Jason or Pozhar.

Fury

Fury is a combination of Jason Rusch and Ronnie Raymond when they were both separate Firestorms. They first turned into Fury while arguing and under extreme duress after being attacked by Zithertech mercenaries. After the first time they used him again to fight Helix and it took them to be mad at each other to become Fury again.

Wrath

Wrath is the combination of Jason Rusch and Firehawk. They combined in Paris while fighting the Justice League International. It took longer to control and was much less stable than Fury. While they controlled it for a very short time, it caused Firehawk pain and when they separated they ended up in Russia. Once Firehawk was able to control herself, she was able to help pull Jason out as he was lost in the quantum field.

Scorn

Scorn is the combination of Ronnie Raymond and Pozhar. He was much more powerful than Fury and all of the other Firestorms, nearly killing Raksashi and Firehawk and killing Hurricane countless Rogues. He was arguably one of the most powerful beings on the planet and was more than willing to use his power as Pozhar was able to direct him completely. He was destroyed when Jason forced his way into the quantum field and became Fury with Ronnie, which was able to overpower Scorn and killed Pozhar as well.

name: Firestorm

deck: Wertham Community Centre Young Offenders, doing community service with superpowers.
description:
Origin

When a freak storm possessing unusual properties struck the London borough of Wertham, it granted many people caught in it superhuman powers, including a group of five young offenders - disgraced athlete Curtis, party girl Alisha, introvert Simon, chav Kelly and foul-mouthed smart alec Nathan - serving out their community service sentences as part of their Anti-Social Behaviour Orders (ASBOs). When their probation worker became a crazed killer in the wake of the storm, the five were forced to kill him and hide his body, a shared secret that brought the disparate group together to become (eventually) unlikely friends.

Creation

The young offenders were created by Howard Overman, and are the stars of the E4 television show Misfits. The five are never referred to in the show as the Misfits, as it is a description more than a team name; indeed, the group are neither a team nor a gang, but rather five very different individuals thrown together by events beyond their control, who gradually, through their shared experiences, become friends to varying degrees. Neither heroes nor villains (despite their minor criminal records), the group are simply trying to survive in a world where they and many around them have been given superpowers they don't particularly want. The closest they have to a "team name" is the press nickname they gained in a now-defunct timeline where they went public: the ASBO Five.
name: Misfits
